results.title: Beethoven, Symphony No. 8 in F Major (Tempo Di Minueto -3rd
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Music in Motion”.
Beethoven often found his musical motives and themes in scenes of nature; scenes of the peacefully flowing Rhine river, ruined castles, leaves turning in the sun, an open field of grain express the charm and individuality of this movement of Beethoven’s Eight Symphony. No other credits are available.

results.brief_description: A performance of the slow movement of the piano trio (nicknamed “The Ghost”) with an analysis of the themes and structure of the movement. No credits available.

results.title: Beethoven or boogie?
results.brief_description: An appreciation of music is instilled in a Youth Club; the members form a Music Group and give a concert to raise money to purchase a radiogram. No other credits available.

results.title: Beethoven lives upstairs
results.creator_credit: Eros Financial Investments, Classical Prod for Children, Richard Mozer and David Devine
results.brief_description: Christoph deeply resents the eccentric new tenant who has moved in upstairs and has turned his home upside-down. Slowly he begins to understand the genius of the man, the torment of his deafness and the beauty of his music, for the tenant is none other than Ludwig Van Beethoven. Set in 19th. century Vienna, this is a lavish production and features excerpts of Beethoven’s best loved works.

results.title: Beethoven and his music
results.brief_description: The music of Beethoven reflects the great social upheaval of the late eighteenth century, the composer’s own unusual strength and genius and the transition from the classic formality of Haydn and Mozart to more romantic expression. The film develops the relationships between Beethoven’s environment and his personal response to it in terms of his music. Excerpts from the following are included in the film. First and Fourth Movement of the Symphony No. 5; The First Movement of the Violin Sonata, Opus 12 no. 2; the First Movement of the Archduke Trio, Opus 97; the First Movement of the Symphony No. 3 “Eroica”; the Piano Sonata No.14, Opus 27, No. 2 “Moonlight”; and the First Movement of the Symphony no. 6 “Pastoral”; the First Movement of the Piano Concerto No. 5 “Emperor”. No other credits available.

results.title: Beethoven
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Marre and Anvil Films and Record Group
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great Composers”.
This film deals with Beethoven’s music up to 1806. John Ogden at the piano plays the “Appassionata” from the “Tempest Sonata” and with Brenda Lucas the early “Sonata for four hands”. Von Karajan conducts Symphony no. 3 (the “Eroica”) op. 55 and the Gabrielli Quartet plays “Rasoumoffsky Quartet” no.2 op.59.

results.title: Beer
results.creator_credit: Television New Zealand, Martin Didsbury and Denis Harvey
results.brief_description: Presents an examination of beer production. Indicates the processing stages, and the resulting outputs of products, by-products and wastes. Chemical processes in fermentation are also considered. The program lends itself to students developing a flow chart of the manufacturing system, with inputs of various values, quantities and types.

results.title: Beefcake
results.creator_credit: Alliance Independent Films, Channel 4 TV, Thom Fitzgerald and Shandi Mitchell
results.brief_description: Based on the life of photographer Bob Mizer who photographed young men for male physique magazines, this is an entertaining combination of fiction and documentary which examines the underground gay culture of America in the 1950s. Centred around Mizer’s trial for obscenity during the McCarthy witch-hunts, “Beefcake” features interviews with models, hustlers and muscle builders from that period as well as creating a fictional narrative about young Neil O’Hara (Joe Pearce), the traditional All-American small-town boy, who arrives in the big city of Los Angeles and becomes immersed in the world of muscles, photography and the incipient gay movement. Filmed in glorious colour which simulates the rainbow palette of the “technicolor fifties”, “Beefcake” is nevertheless a highly insightful look into the cost of repression. The film acknowledges the complexity of Mizer’s relationship with the young men he photographed, as well as his initially tender but ultimately destructive relationship with his mother, who encouraged his work but refused the evidence of his sexuality. And though “Beefcake” suggests that Mizer’s world allowed young gay men freedom for the first time in their lives, it also examines how Mizer himself was blind to the effects of drugs and loneliness on his young subjects. The interviewees include Warhol superstar Joe Dellasandro who began his career as a Physique magazine model.

results.title: Beef, grass and dairy calves
results.brief_description: This film is designed to demonstrate to farmers the new techniques of calf rearing which can be successfully incorporated into existing farming systems. It underlines the higher productivity and therefore greater profitability which results from the new methods when and if they are used.
